title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in Section 2. In this Act, a "business entity" is defined as any organization established for profit through commerce in the United States. "Commerce" is defined as in the Consumer Product Safety Act. A "consumer" is an individual in the US who purchases goods or services for personal use. "Customer service communication" refers to interactions between consumers and business entities in commerce. Service communication refers to telecommunication or wire communication between a consumer and a business entity in commerce. Telecommunication involves the transmission of chosen information without alteration, while wire communication involves the transmission of various forms of data through wire, cable, or similar connections. SEC. 3. REQUIRED DISCLOSURE BY BUSINESS ENTITIES ENGAGED IN CUSTOMER SERVICE COMMUNICATIONS OF PHYSICAL LOCATION. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, unless all employees involved are in the United States or if the communication was initiated by the consumer to a foreign entity. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, unless the communication is initiated by the consumer and the employee or agent is located outside the United States. Emergency services are exempt from this requirement. The Federal Trade Commission may exclude certain business entities or customer service communications from these requirements under exceptional circumstances. Each year, business entities participating in customer service communications must certify their compliance to the Federal Trade Commission. The Federal Trade Commission requires business entities to certify compliance with customer service communication regulations. Regulations must be promulgated within one year of the Act's enactment, and the requirements apply to communications one year after the Act's enactment date. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with section 3 of the Act will be treated as a violation of a regulation under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission has the power to prevent violations of the Act and its regulations, with penalties and privileges similar to those under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission Act provisions are incorporated into this Act, preserving the authority of the Federal Trade Commission under any other law.
